What Does Shiro Mean in Korean (싫어)? “Shiro” (written as 싫어 in Hangul) is used when you really dislike something. It can mean:
I don’t want to I hate it I dislike that It’s a strong emotional refusal—not just a calm “no.”
Depending on tone, it can sound:
😤 Frustrated: “I don’t want to!” 😅 Playful: “Nooo, I don’t like that!” 😠 Defiant: “I hate that idea.” How to Write “Shiro” in Hangul Here’s the breakdown of the word 싫어:
First syllable: 싫 (shir) Second syllable: 어 (uh) The romanization shiro is a simplified pronunciation. In reality, the first syllable has a slightly blocked “r/l” sound combined with “shi.”
When writing Hangul stroke-by-stroke, focus on:
The ㅅ and ㄹ combo in 싫 The soft open vowel 어 What It Looks Like How It’s Used in K-Dramas (And Real Life) You’ll hear “shiro!” in situations like:
A character refusing to go on a blind date Someone rejecting food or a gift A child protesting doing homework A love confession that’s denied emotionally What’s the Difference Between Shiro and Aniyo? Phrase Hangul Meaning Tone Shiro 싫어 I don’t like it Emotional, strong, informal Aniyo 아니요 No (polite) Neutral, respectful Use “Aniyo” in polite conversation.
Use “Shiro” when your feelings are strong—or when acting like your favorite drama lead.
